THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

p.hi: Public Analyst for the City of Glasgow and the Counties of Lanark, Renfrew, &c.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette. "
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. div.head: A TRIUMPH OF BRITISH BRIDGE-BUILDERS
div.p: The new road bridges over the Nile at Cairo, says "Engineering”, are now completed, have been tested, and will be opened in a few dayo for tramway, vehicular, and pedestrian traffic. Our contemporary publishes illustrations of the structures as they now stand, and details of the testa. It was in the summer of 1903 that the Egyptian Guverndicat inued specifications suviting tenders and designs for three roads. bridges to be constructed over the Nile at Cairo. Por each bridge, thirty eight designs of tenders were received from thirteen firma, six of whom were French, one each German, Belgian, Italian, and Swiss, and three British, se of wbw submitted an American design. It will be seen that the competition was interna cional, and excited keen interest The Belgian torm alone submitted nine different designs for the large bridge, and three for each of the call bridges. As many as sixty to seventy drawings accompanied each tender, and in many cases general and detailed perspective drawings were attached to them. It w ati cated that the preparation of all the designs be represented an expenditure of about 25100V A mission was appointed to examine the designs and calculations and nsport to the Government. After a careful and prolonged examination of the various proposals the designs and tender of the joint firms of Sir William Arrol and Co, Limited of Glasgow and Mowers Head, Wrightson, and Co, Limited, of Middlesbrough, were scepted for construct in the three bridges, at a cost of 192.000% This result, continues "Bugineering was most gratifying, at a time when so much was being written about the inability of British facturers to compete with their Continental rivals The main bridge cross from Basel bear the road to the Pyramide to the Island of Rodah, and the two smaller bridges from Bodah Island to the main road leading to Old Cairu. The successful designs were prepared by the civil engineering staff of Sir William Arrol and Co., Limited. The main bridge in 1755 ft. in length between abutments, divided into 10 pas of 140ft, two ed spes of 70 ft. ad double-swing spar 220 ft. in length, with two clear openings of 66 it. The bridge is 20 metres in width, or 66 ft., between parapete divided into two footpaths ft. wide and roadway of so it in width, of which 16it is allocated to the tramways and 39 t to the roade The opening spas, adds "Engineering" is operated by two 30 brake horsepower electric motors setting through gearing on to the thok, sada be opened or closed in 3 minutes, including the time for all operations necessary in ob pectionwith the swinging The bridge have been officially tested by the Government with most satisfactory results. It is only necessary to quote from the late Sir Benjamin Baker reported your ago :-"As regarde material and workmanship, the bridge is entirely a tie factory, and in all respects the structure is fine example of the high class of work which CAD Dow be turned out by bridge builders of great experience, whose manufacturers are supplied with all the most modern appliances

div.head:
KHEDIVIAL RECEPTION INCIDENT
EXPULSION OF A SHEIKH
div.p: Considerable discussion has been aroused in native circles by the treatment of Sheikh Razi, one of the ulema of the Al Azhar University at the last reception held by H H the Khedive. It is averred that the learned Sheikh was peremptorily ordered by the Grand Master of Ceremonies to quit the Palace and that instructions were issued to the soldiers of the Khedivial guard and to the police responsible for this gentleman's entrance to furbid bius Admission in the future. However this may be, the Sheikh left Abdin in high dudgeon and it can only be supported that the disfavour of His Highness was the cause of his expulsion. Abbas II is unlikely to have ordered the expulsion of an Alim from the Palace, above all on an occasion on which all the Moslem world is en fête, without good reasons and the report that Sheikh Razi had been guilty of proposing almost revolutionary measures dignified by enemies of the ancient and celebrated Moslem: University with the title of Schemes for reform'-which were highly displeasing to his fellow Ulems seems to us to restore some solid foundation. In any case we may be assured that H. H. the Khedive-who has in any case a perfect right to refuse to receive persons in wbom be bas no confidence is too far above the tumult of party strife and too inground in the pursuit not of his private but of the public interest, to have instructed his Grand Master of the Ceremonies to take any such action for merely personal reasons. At the same time we regret that no measures were taken to warn Sheikh Razi before the neweption that his presence at Abdin was not desired. for any such incident - which loses nothing in the telling-is to be regretted, more especially when it occurs under such conditions

div.head:
DR. RUTHERFORD, M.P.
HIS DEPARTURE FROM EGYPT.
div.p: Dr. Rutherford, MP, left Cairo yesterday morning for Port Said in order to return home in time for the opening of Parliament. When leaving be cordially thanked his friends who came to the station to bid him farewell, for all the attentions that had been shown to him and for the beautiful and costly jewels sod treasures, which his admirers had bestowed upon him. He also expressed his warm appreciation of the universal urbanity, with which he had been received by the British officials and the facilities afforded him by Dr. Dunlop sod his eminent Anglo-Boption colleges for pouring his investigations into educational and other administrative mysteries. Mr. Rotberford spent Sunday on a visit to Mansonnab. He was specially struck with the ability and intelligence of Mustapha Pasha Maber, the popular Moudir tberg, whose intellectual capacity and liberal sympathie deeply impressed the Scotch Radical M.P. Here he noted, was at all events a B and an Egyptian, who was ripe for self-government. Dr. Rutherford. M.P., reflected that conceivably there might be many others like him, scattered throughout the length and breadth of the country, who had attained the same high level of mental capacity. From sub examples be derived mueb encouragement for bi pet theory that a larger share of Government and responsibility should be conferred upon the Egyptian people. Accompanied by the Moudit, the MP., visited the primary and technical schools, and made detailed and exhaustive inspection of these educational establishments. He also sawa girls sebool, which much pleased him. The want, however, of a secondary school at Mar south was strongly commented upon by him. Dr. Rutherford has been favourably impressed with all that he has seen, but his visit, so far as could be gleaned, has not obliged his political a priori intentions on the difficult theory of Egyptian Administration. He has made a deep study of Egypt in books and reports and has digested the voluminous an bual reports of Lord Cromer with amazing scrupulousness His fortnight's visit to this country will therefore give him . panoply for entering the arena of parliamentary debate fully primed to deal with every detail of Egypt in Administration, which comes before the notice of the House of Commons. He will be able to ask most searching questions about Egypt's internal organisation and will ply Sir Edward Grey with crucial problems to technical details of management and control Dr. Rutherford, M.P., is of somewhat reserved character and does not unburthe himself to the pertinacious interviewer However, as far as we can gather, the above represents our intelligent anticipation of what is likely to take place. There is a theory widely held among the ardent lative politicians

div.head:
THE CAIRO SEASON
SAVOY HOTEL DANCE.
div.p: It speaks well for the resource of the Savoy Hotel that on Saturday evening its management was able to serve the big banquet given by the Constitutional League to De Rutherford, M.P., which included covers for reventy in room at one end of the hotel at the same time that the usual number of Saturday dinner parties were in progress in the restaurant. The number in the latter place were even more numerous than usual extra tables being placed in another room leading out of the restaurant to accomodate the guests

Miss Cochrane who generally entertains guests on Saturday nights had a larger party than usual: among them being Colonel and Mos Herbert Mr. and MrsRoyle Lady Oppenheim, Captain and Mn. Darell, Colonel Harvey Push, Colonel Cuthbert, Major Owen, Mr. & Mrs Clifford Hall Min Cochrane Mise Hocier, Mise Evelyn and the Moon Heywood Lady Barttelot’s table for eight included Captain and Mrs. Dunbar, Mr. and Schreiber, Miss Baird, Captain Lane and Mr. Byre. At Count Koti Brodsky's table were ibe Marquis Moravanti, Baron Villefangen Baron Hein, Donut Strassold, Band and Baroness Altred de Menas, Mr. and Mme de Zoltan, and Mr. de Waguer. With Mr. A B Gardner were Mr. and Mr. Sibthorpe Barlow, Mr. Adde, Mr. P. O. Gardner and others: Captain and Mrs Duffos were entertaining Mrs. and Miss Wholen. Mr. and Mrs Moncture Robinson, and Dr. Tribe Captain kennedy's party included Mrs. and Mis Park Lyle who have but lately returned to Cairo Major Haigh with Captain and Mrs Potagerald. If any proof was needed to show how the son has improved of late, a glimpse into the ballroom later on would have been sufficient to convince pessimists that there is plenty of life even now in Cairo. It was perhaps the most festive function we have seen this winter, and we hear that some of the supper parties might still have been found in the restaurant till close upon three o'clock in the morning. div.head: WINTER RESORT RIVALRY
div.p: A correspondent write from the Riviera

The proprietors of the various health and pleasure morte here are making stresom effort to prevent fares in their power lies to do the soul rush to opt which sally takes place at about this time of the year. The fact that e bolers has appeared in the leaning Need upon excellent inducement to the tourist to postpone his departure from Europe but even before this dins had made its appearance there were dire tales of plague and death going the round of the Continental hotels even some of the shipping agents having so far to advise intending passengers to delay their departure as count of the terrible reports of plague just received 1 One can only imagine vaguely the inducements which must have been put before the eyes of such an agent before he could be brought to forego the profits which would seere to him in the natural way on every passenger who booked through his office. It is able to conclude that there must have been advantages of very exceptional value for the shipping agent, in addition to losing his ordinary profit of the moment, runs the risk of losing his deleted client for all time should the falsity of these statements be brought to light. But though these tales may, and undoubtedly do, carry a certain Amount of weight with the tourist who is vectoring to the Past for the first time they are powerless to impress the moved traveller, who indeed appears to regard them see recommendation to his favourite haunted inwoh if they lacked the chara which he has claimed for them over the attractions of the Continent there would be no need to make this attempt of belittling them. Last year it was the supported sod wholly imaginary danger of Native rising which was urged good and sufficient reason to the would be traveller to remain in Barope Then it was the plague bow it is the cholera What will it be nextil Let them go through the seven plagues of Egypt and still Ropt will hold the imagination and affections of the weekers after health and quiet who wander through the world in search of spot where the two na be som bined in a civilised country.

div.head: THE FINANCIAL SITUATION
div.p: To The EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE”

Dear Sir,- A Cairo correspondent of the continental "Daily Mail," writing from Cairo in December, calls attention to the continuance of financial depression in Egypt and points out that the want of ready money is affecting all classes and nationalities in the country and continues "The fall in market values which met in last March has continued, land owners who sold their cotton early in the year have been paid only in part while in the share market securities which were quoted at £5 or £6 are now offered at about £1. Complaint is made in European business circles that the Banks are attempting nothing to relieve the situation. The Government is criticised for its passive attitude......... "The crisis has touched the national prosperity to a severe degree."

All the above is most certainly true, and unfortunately there appears to be no prospect of affairs righting themselves as we anticipated in the new year. Rents continue to stand at exorbitant figures, living becomes more expensive daily, and money is as tight to-day as it was in the early days of the crisis. The banks refuse to make advances now on the security of stock to people whose signature would have been considered sufficient a year ago. To put the whole thing in few words every man doubts the financial stability of his neighbour with the result that a feeling of distrust prevails throughout the whole business community of Cairo, and until money is forced into circulation by some means or other there can be no prospect of renewed prosperity. There are rumours of the Government being called upon to relieve the situation by loan of two million to the country. It Is likely that the Government will consider a pro position of this kind, and if it did would the loan be of any real service to the country at large It would of course tend to keep things going for the time being, but would it be of any material assistance to the guarantee of financial security in the future. I for one doubt fit, it might keep the heads of several of our too numerous companies above water and it would certainly keep the rents at their present exorbitant standard. Would this be an advantage! I think not
Yours etc.

div.head: Bairam Festivities
div.p: The Greek New Year and the first day of Kurban Bairsm happens to have fallen on the same day this year, and we have therefore bad the combined festival of both communities This naturally caused partial cowtion of official business on the 14th and an almost complete stoppage of general trade for two or three days As usual the Moslems and Greeks, but especially the former, have spent much of their holiday time in driving in and about the towns. This seems to be a specially popular form of amusement st such times and is generally accompanied by a small amount of shooting and singing On the occasion of the last Bairam several accidents occurred from furious driving, and earrings drivers have this year been warned against indalging in this practice under threat of the loss of their licenses.

div.head: Severe Weather
div.p: Snow has fallen again heavily on the South era range, throughout its entire length, and almost to the base of the mountains, and very old weather, though bright and clear, is now prevailing

div.head: Concert At Nicola
div.p: A grand concert was given on the 10th instant at the Papadopoullos Theatre, Nicosia, "In sid of Consumptive Pend." The performance was held under the patronage of his Excellency the High Commissioner and Lady King Harman, who were present. The boom was unfortunately, by no means full have seen it, but the expec could not have been heavy. It may be hoped that a ti fotory sum was nevertheless, realised to be placed to the credit of the Pand. The entertainment provided was good, and though not very varied in character, was very creditable to the small baglish community, who with one exception supplied the musical talent on the occasion. Particularly noteworthy was the really fine duet for two pianos most excellently played by Mr. G. Smith and Mo Ami rayan. The performance WM was almost faultless and both ladies excelled themselves and delighted the audience Mn. Bertram ng charm ingly, her rendering of "Should be upbraid" being immensely appreciated and provoking an encore. A violin solo by Miss I. Spencer, and a violin trio by Miss L. Spencer, Mr. Beknill and Mis I. Gore were welcome contributions and were much enjoyed and heartily appland ed. The programme was completed by excellent songs from Col. Gore, Capt. Durham Hall, Rev. F. LIEdwarda, and Mr. &. Since the existence of the Nicosia Pamagosta Railway it has become customary for Pema gusta residents to train to Nicosia for any entertainment of this sort and to return to their district theme night. This provides them with • pleasant opportunity of taking part in historical events at the capital and at the me time adds materially to the taking of any charitable performance

div.head: Annual Show
div.p: The annual Animal Show has today been held at the metropolis under the auspices of the Committee for the improvement of the Brood of Cyprus Stock. This event is molly fixed for Kourbam Bair , which, being a moveable feast occurring a fortnight earlier every year, has brought it about that this Show is now being held in the depth of the Winter. In course of time presumably thin feast will take place in the setumn instead of the winter, and the Animal Show Mociated with it will then fall close upon the Omodne Animal Show, which is regular fixture fre the 27th September. Doubtlen arrangement will be made to obviate this, but, under present conditions, not a few livestock owners must be deterred from showing their apmak by a reasonable objection to exposing them to the biting wind, which so often prevails, wit has done to day, at this time of year.

div.head: Zaptieh Sports
div.p: Tomorrow the Zaptieh Sports will be held, as usual, in the Most at Nicosia. This is very popular fixture and draws a large crowd. Invitations to test are out to leading persons and personal friends of the Police. officials, as in former years

div.head: LIVE-STOCK HAWKING.
div.p: "TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Sir,-Is there no authority in the city which can put a stop to the cruelty perpetrated under our very eyes? One constantly sees live pigeons, fowls, and ducks tied tightly by the legs hawked about the streets for sale. How long they are kept in this torture heaven alone knows, but the agony they must endure is undeniable. This day in the Rue Cherif Parba I saw a native offering for sale on 19 or 15 live wild ducks tied in benches by the lege with cord sad slang over beholder Presumably some of these wretched bride would remain in this position the whole day and being wild their leg wooldsboetied until some prohor bad pait need to their offerings Baskets made from the items of palm le you are within the road of all hati and Invention to think that if there be my Authority with power to omog roh order no native should be allowed to hawk live birde or simal except in baskets of suitable size
Yours faithfully

div.head: HEAT IN AUSTRALIA
div.p: MELBOURNE, January 20. Great boats are felt in Australia. The temperature is daily over 100 in the shade here and in Adelaide. 32 deaths have occurred in Victoria.

div.head: THE COTTON DISPUTE.
div.p: MANCHESTER, January 20. Lock-out notices have been posted up in over 90% of the lancashire mills, but pour parlors through a private mediator, hitherto anonymous, are making such progress that settlement appears imunindot

div.head: PORT ARTHUR TRIAL
div.p: St. PETERSBURG, January 20. The Port Arthur trial is marked by bitter recriminations on the part of Geuerala Stoessel! and Smirnoff. The latter declared that General Stoessel did not participate in the fighting and defence but merely issued lyrical orders announcing decorations, and that be usurped General Smirnoff's position in order to capitulate

div.head: MID-DEVON ELECTION
div.p: London, January 20. The Liberal papers admit that though local transitory causes contributed, the Mid Devou le election was a notable victory for tariff reform, on which the election was fought. They deeply regret the liberal rowdyism at Nowton Abbot

div.head: LORD CURZON
div.p: LONDON, January 20. Lord Curzon has been elected an Irish Peer. It is understood that be had a considerable majority

div.head: THE PREMIER
div.p: LONDON, January 20. Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman has arrived.

div.head: RUSSIAN TERRORISTS ARRESTED.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURO, January 20.. - A man and woman, believed to be the leading members of a Russian terrorist party, have been arrested in Paris whilst attempting to change notes plundered from the Treasury van at Tiflis in July last. A woman and two men have also been arrested at Munich under similar circumstances. The Russian police attach great importance to the arrests

div.head: THE LUGH INCIDENT.
div.p: ROME, January 20 The Italian reinforcements have reached Lugh and found that the Abyssinians had retired towards Karanle, Other reinforcements have been sent to Bareera.

div.head: PERSIAN FINANCES
div.p: PARIS. January 20. Peria has requested the assistance of a French oficial in order to reorganize her finances, M. Bizet, Inspector of Finances, has been appointed with the title of Financial Adviser.

div.head: A Train Disaster
div.p: Rome, January 21.

A train from Milan to Rome crashed into the rear of a train proceeding to Pavia at Acquabella bridge yesterday evening. The engine of the former and the rear carriages of the latter were overturned. A third train from Bergamo dashed into the wreck Up to the present 9 bodies have been recovered. The Minister, Signor Carcang, and a number of Senators who were passengers proceeding to attend the Nasi trial, escaped, uninjured (Router)

div.head: CHOLERA INCREASING.
div.p: JEDDAH, January 20.
The cholera is increasing. There are now 400 deaths daily. (Reuter)

div.p: LONDON, January 20.
Sir Massey Lopes is dead. (Router)

div.head: MOSLEM FESTIVAL IN LONDON.
div.p: "The Feast of Sacrifice," one of the great anniversaries of the Moslem year, corresponding in importance to Christmas or the lowish Passover, was celebrated last Tuesday with the picturesque ceremonial of the East at the Holborn Restaurant, London, by Mohammedans resident in England. Followers of the Prophet of every tint, from pale to darkest brown assembled at eleven o'clock in the Kingsway Saloon, an oblong apartment dimly lighted by stained glass windows. The floor had been carpeted with a number of white table-cloths. Law students and basics men generally, the worshippers represented almost all the races which have embraced the religion-Turks, Indians, Persians, Ceyloupse, Arabs -- and, though in European dress, many were adorned with the gorgeous flowing turban or the vari-coloured fer. These were worn during the service; the Western top and round hats were discarded and the worshippers, with one consent, removed their boots and stood in stockinged feet. Many improvised turbans out of silk handkerchiefs. The Feast of "sacrifice which the Islamic Society celebrates annually is held in memory of the great pre-Islamio sacrifice of Ismael by Abraham, which the Moslems believe in in preferen: ce to the Christian tradition of Isaac.

div.head: BUSINESS PROSPECTS IN THE SUDAN
div.p: II**The previous article appeared on July 23

A correspondent writes as follows to the financial supplement of the Times In my previous article I showed how the basinars development of the Saden is támapered in all directions by the system of administration, and I will now deal with the more important defects ol that system.

The chief and constant complaint of the Sudan Government officials is that they are peatered and pampered incessantly by pile of petty account, which always claim their prompt attention. The consequence is that their more important work suffers, they have bnt little timo in offee hours oven to bonsider 10 In fact all those who are most capable of forming opinions and studying schemes for the development of the country's resources are scarily ever permitted an opportunity to meet for the purpose of exchanging and to cording their idees

A committo composed of the chiefs of various departments was appointed over a year ago at Khartoum, and entitled the Central Economic Board, the object of which was to advise the Government as regards all-nekured connected with the general advancement of commerce and economic research. The idea was most praiseworthy, and it should have received the full support of the Government ; | but its nueces depends upon the determination of the committee to meet frequently, and another weak point is the constitution of the Board. Its members have been selected from among the most practical men in the service, but they are all Government officials, with no special incentive to deviate their leisure time to the work of the Board As the general advancement of commerce isole of the avowed objects of the Board, it could do no harm if a few of the local bankers and merchants were included in its constitution. Possibly such men would be too young or inexperienced to express opinions of great weight, but they could refer to their bead offices in Cairo or Alexandria for advice, and they might even aet, under proper restrictions, as mouth-pieces of such representative institutions as the General Produce Association of Alexandria and the British Chamber of Commerce in Egypt Questions concerning the advancement of commerce in the Badan have naturally great interest for these institutions, which possess special facilities for obtaining the opinions of experienced merebants and financiers, and they have usually been found willing to respond to invitations from official quarters for reports on matters of general interest: In this way much valuable information could be given to the men who have been appointed to advise the Government, and who, admittedly, have little if any practical experience connected with commercial matters. But it is essential that the Board should hold meetings regularly at short intervals, and that the cause of their inability to do so bitberto should be removed.
OFFICIALS AND ACCOUNTS.

This brings me to the root of most of the administrative troubles of the Governmentnamely, the need of an adequate yet simple system of accounts. It is really a question of the first importance, because not only does the effective use of every department depend upon it, but it is the chief factor to be considered in regard to the proper development of the country, and for the following rea-ons :

The most efficient and valuable men in the State service are compelled, to sorrow, to sacrifice the greater portion of their time to the deaseless and seemingly futile demands of the Accounts Department. The responsibility of disbursing petty cash in most commercial houses is usually entrusted to a junior clerk under reasonable control, for the simple reason that it is economically unsound to occupy the time of senior men with petty detail of any kind. In the Sudan Government service no item of expenditure is too small to evade the ordeal of being recorded on several official forms, which are checked and counterchecked and sigued by various clerks until they are approved and signed by the chief clerk. Then they all have to be sanctioned and approved, signed and countersigned, by the head of the department before being sent in to the Finan: cial Department offices, where they are again checked and counterchecked, signed and countersigned, by many employdi, and whence they often return for correction or adjustment All such corrections and adjustments have to be submitted to the same laborious series of operations, and as they are too often made the subject of much needless correspondence, the burden of this process is thereby increased to s very serious degree. Noofficial can get as moob As a bottle of ink or even a postage stamp for his office without signing soveral of such applica tions, official returns, and other forms, all of which bave to be filled in with scrupulous exactitude by his clerks, when at headquarters, or by himself when on tour in the provinces! If he has, say, five subordinates employed in the provinces on public works, garvey, educational, or other duties, the preparation of such doopments increases tenfold, and one stands appalled at this colossal waste of time.

It seems almost incredible that an official who is entrusted with the administration of the affairs of a whole province is not allowed the financial responsibility of a junior clerk in a counting house. Yet such is the melan. choly fact, and, as a consequence, I have often seen the busiest officials engaged for many hours in merely attaching their signatures to heaps of documents which they could not possibly examine and great proportion of which related to nothing more important than the sending of a threepenny telegram of the engaging of a camel driver. And it must not be sappoord that they have seen the last of those official "terms" and "retams," distinguished by various titles and numbers, after being sent to the Financial Department On the contrary, they emerge in course of time to be despatched to the Accounts Department in Cairo, where they are once more checked and counter checked, signed and counter-signed by another staff of officials who apportion the various items of expenditure to their respective positions in the State accounts. They are then returned to their authors for further signatures and reports; bat as it would be too monotonous to follow them to their final resting place we will now leave these exasperating documents.
MULTIPLICATION OF CORRESPONDENCE

In 1902, Colonel Drage, the Controller of the Revenue Department, reported that the expenditure on stationery by the Sudan Government in the preceding year was L E 600 in excess of the estimates, and he remarked that "nothing londa itself more to wasto and extravagant use than stationery.". Thereupon Lord Cromer draw attention to the matter in the following observation :-"I venture to express a hope that a steady check will be kept con excessive centralization, and the Sodan is pre eminently a country where the administration should be decentralized 88 much as possible."

Lord Cromer has frequently alluded to the tendency which exists among officials in Egypt to multiply correspondence utbedersarily, and it may not be out of place to mention a typical instance of this abuse which he cited in his last report (Egypt, No 1, 1907) It consisted of an official file of 81 typewritten pages relating to the case of a certain wise man who had boeght from his nephew half of a donkey for a sum rather less than £2. A doubt arose as to whether the donkey had been bought or stolen; and on this subject 73 official notes were record ed by various officials residing at Caito or el sewhere. The question of the ownership of the donkey bad been under discussion for one year and nine months, yet in November last it was apparently still unsettled. In ady other sphere of life such lamentablo waste of time and energy would have been avoided by paying somebo dy the £2 or shooting the donkey.

One oan sympathise with the feelings of Colonel Stewart, a remarkably able officer, when he wrote his report on the Sudan in 1882, the last official report insued before the Mahdist oecupation Egypt, No. 11, 1883). In this report be made soine suggestions for the future go yerument of the country from which I may te peat the two following ones, namely: -

A department for the Sudan frances to be attached to the Ministry of fiuanoe ait Oairo, This departmeot should be more of an auditing office, and should not interfere with the executive finance office at Khartum.

A qualified official to be sent to the Sudan to reorganize the system of publio offices and introduce a national mode of bookkeeping. At present it is impossible for any outsider to un derstand the system of accounts, and the num ber of choclos and counter obecks 80 seriously increase business that notwithstanding the present enormous staff, extra olerks have frequently to be called in.

The first of the two suggestions was eventually adopted; but the department which is still retained in Cairo bas attain noch dimen wions as woro prabably never contemplated by its promoter. Its maintenance was doubtles considered necessary so long as the Sudan was administered as a province of Egypt but under the new wiginis ita practical ability has, to all intents and purposes, disappeared, and therefore it might vary well be abandoued and transfer rol in a modified form to the rest of the Go. vernment at Khartum. The effect of such a mi) ve would be to sconomize the vast amount of time and labour which is expendel at present in corresponding, upon such a complicated subjostas scouts, with a department situated so di tagt from the headquarters of all ober branches of the service I might here romark that a further domy should be made at the samo timo by closing the office which was open od in Alexandrie some years ago to attend to the clearing and despatch of material destined for the Sudan railwaya. It is still maintained at considerable expense, although its existence is op longer justified since the opening of Port Sudan.

In regard to the second of Colonel Stewart's suggestions which I have quoted, the first por ton, involving the reorganization of the system of public officials, asight very well be relerred to the Central Boonomie Board for examination. The ergonoy of this question is clearly rebog nized and frankly admitted by almost all the State officials, and if amplo Assistance is pro vided for its investigation, I have 09 doubt that the Board will soon be able to propose s practical solation
INFERIORITY OF EMPLOYEES

The bottor class of Bayptian olerks will not as a rule, go to the Sudan, and I think that the Sudan will ultimately find reason to con gratulate itself over their disinclination to go there, for they are not appreciated in Egypt by any English banker or morebant. lo the meantime, however, the progress of adminis. trative schemen is seriously impeded in every direotion by employke of a very inferior order who are generally incompetent and lazy, who often go siok on the sligbtgat pratast, and, to som up, who are very dar indoed at the price of their wagos.

What is the remedy 1 It is to employ English clerks There are thousands of young English alerks, between 30 and 30 years of age, available in England today, bodily and mo Tally sound,, healthy and active intelligent honest, and fairly well educated, who wonta eagerly apply for enployment in the Sudan Government service under fair conditions of openeration and leave. A man of this kind Would, sooppt, Na matter of couns the to ponsibilities which all Egyptian employ Whirtel absolutely. He should be able, if required, to take down in shorthand ble bhios instructions as quickly as he could atter them, and type write them in rather less time, thus saving him the labour of three quarters of his corrrespondence. He could perform the duties of his post in the conscientious manner which is so familiar to us in England, but so sadly lack: Ling 18" & Levantine and many Oriental 18-1 tions, and after 12 months service he ought to be capable of relieving his chief of at least I the bulk of the detail work which at present clogs his brain and hampers every effort to improve and extend the efficiency and use fulness of his department.

I have not attempted to describe what might be regarded as a paragon of virtue by officials unacquainted with the working of a well-equip. ped comercial office in London I have merely mentioned the usual qualifications which English clerks are now required to pos-1 sess in order to obtain good employment in London business houses.

The principal objections which have been raised by Sudan Government officials to the suggested employment of English clerks are that suitable quarters could not be found for them in Khartoum, and that their salaries would be expensive. I do not consider that either of these objentions présents any serious difficolty. The average Englishman is moreindependent and capable of fending for himself abroad than any other nation's occasional representative, and if a demand were to arise for fairly cheap and comfortable lodgings in in Khartouun, I have no doubt whatever that the supply would soon be forthcoming. Young | men wBo owigrate to the Colonies, for example, do not ask or expect to be surrounded by un accustomed laxuries, or even to meet with the standard of home comforts which has been faniliar to them from boy hood.

As regards the expense, it would be no exaggeration to state that three English clerks could easily do, the work which in the Soudan is at present alloted to ten incompetent men, and that the aggregate day of these ten men would provide adequate salaries for their three English substitutes ahd still leave a consider able surplus.

Before leaving this subject I venture to add a suggestion that no bard-and fast lines should be drawn in regard to the scale of pay for the English clerks I have been recommending Rules are made to be stretched--at the right mothent; and there is nothing which has such a deadening influence on human initiative and the exercise of individual ability as the know ledge that you are receiving the marimum pay allowed to men of your rank, and that you cannot hope for promotion to higher ranks Therefore I believe that the Sudan Government would be wise in arranging that these men, after a reasonable term of service, might be recommended for higher rates of pay according to individual merit. It is a very young Government, and it has got to create a Civil Service; it is not fettered with the old-fashioned traditions and shibboleths of old-Governments, and therefore, it can afford to be unconventional. It is poor économy to engage men of high professional attainment for the purpose of developing new departments of State without providing them with intelligent subordinates, because under such conditions their abilities are Wasted upon trifles, and their energy is Kable, in such a climate, to flag before they are free to deal with more important matters

The latter portion of Colonel Stewart's second suggestion relates to the introduction of & rational mode of bookkeeping, and I think I have already said enough to show that his opinion in this respect was not followed
THE GOVERNMENT'S Accounts.

It takes five months to prepare and publish the annual statement of seconots of the Sudan Government, and this fact alone would seem to indicate the existence of some serious defect in their system of bookkeeping. The annual state: mont shows the receipts and expenditure of the various provinces and departments, also the situation of the reserve fund ; but no provision is apparently made for capital account and no assets are shown. I am not qualified to speak with each weight on this complex subject, but I think I may venture to suggest that the railways, stearns and boats, agriculture and lands and certain other departments might be allowed, with advantage, to have their resp80-1 tive capital accounts.

As regards assets, I may point out that in Khartum alone the Government possess several square miles of the best building sites ou the river front and in other positions, and as the present marketable price of adjoining plots may be taken as 20s. the square metru at a modetate estimate, it seems clear that this land represents a State asset of considerable value. lo Khartum North, on the opposite bank of the Nile, the Governtient occupy all the land except one plot far distant from the railway! terminus. Sooner or later they will have to abandon their barracks, workshops, and storeyards there and make way for commerce Most, if not the whole of Omdurman belongs to the State, and in Port Sudan there is but one landlord, for the Government own the entire foreshore, and everything beyond it.

These various properties will increase in value rapidly when com nercial men are encouraged to enter the country, and even bow they could be partially used withont moob difficulty as a means of aaising loads, and thereby releasing the Budan from its dependenca opon the annual contrib tion from the Egyptian Treasury Among other "assets we may surely include the railway rolling stock and plant, as also the steamers and boats

In such matters, however, it is essential to have expert opinion. Just as we consult doctors, lawyers, or engineers for professional advice in matters connected vith their respective spheres, so we should call in the chartered accountant to revise our system of accounts. Tho evils of a complicated system are so pronounced and so generally recognized nowadays that they are no longer tolerated by important business concerns. Most limited liability companies are compelled by the force of public opinion to have their accounts organized and audited by chartered accountants, and there is no lack of evidence to prove that the economies effected in time and laboor by their assistance have been most highly appreciated in commercial circles.

It is absolutely necessary that the reorganization of the present system of accounts abould be carried out by a professional Accountant, as he would enter upon his duties with an open mind, and his position would naturally be quite independent. There are many excellent firms of chartered accountants in London who could deal with the work efficiently and rapidly, and it will be a great pity if it is not commenced very soon. The Sudan Administration is only about seven years old, and therefore its accounts can be overhauled without an abnormal amount of difficulty, but if the work is postponed the present system will soon become perfectly unwieldy, and the cost of reorganization will then be very heavy.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The 1st Battalion of the Green Howards.is getting ready at Aldershot for their Egyptian tour of service As already intimated, it will embark on the 16th-inst for Alexandria, at Southampton on board the troopship Soudan and will reach Alexandria on the Inst day of the month, yia Gibraltar, Malta, and Limasol The battalion' has just been clothed throughout with tropical wear, including three suits of khaki drill, and the new.colonial pattern serge, faced with the historio green of the corps. The battaliou will have an embarking strength of some 850, of all ranks under the command of Lieutenant Colonel E. MB-on, and Major C. A. C. King second in command. Aghiolast inspection, the other day, General Herriker Major paid a high compliment to the efficiency, drill süd disciplino, of the Green Howards, particularly referring to the non-commissioned officers, and wishing all ranks every success in their coming tour.
Second Lieutenant E. D. H. Tollemache, 3rd Battalion Coldstreara Guards, Cairo, has been promoted lieutenant after two and a half years' service in his late grade. .

The reinforcing draft for the 8rd Cold streamers will accompany the Green Howard to Alexandria This does not look like immediato dissolution on part of the battalion: There is a shrewd suspicion that Mr. Haldane is pretty well sick of his reductions for the sake of "economy with efficiener" Gallant little Wales, which supported him warmly until he has ordered several battalions of Militia and Volunteers to be disbanded, is now going for him in a whole hearted manner.
Lieutenant W Gillatt, Royal Army Medical Corps has been seconded for service with the Egyptian Army.

Captain and Quartermaster W. Jenson, 3rd Battalion Coldstream Guards, is about to retire from his service, and Serjeant Major P.T. Priceboard, superintending clerk at the regimental headquarters of the Coldstreamers has been selected to fill the appointment. Mr. Prichard has served for twenty three years in the Guards, and for the past ten bus beld warrant rank.

Commander L G. Preston, who rendered anch magnificent service to destroyer "Ariel" when she was wrecked on Malta breakwater early last year, has just taken over the command of the Devonport flotilla of destroyers. It may be recalled that he was promoted specially to his present rank in connection with the incident referred to above

Sub Lieutenant the Honourable Roger Coke, from the destroyer Express has been appointed to the battleship Prince of Wales, flagship of H.S. Prince Louis of Battenberg, to date from the 30th inst. Mr. Coke is the son of Viscount Coke, sad Chandson of the Earl of Leicester. He was appointed to a cadetship in the navy just five years ago

div.head: FRENCH TRADE WITH AFRICA
div.p: The "Board of Trade Journal ''published some interesting statistics showing the large expansion of French trade with Africa between 1903 and 1906. The aggregate imports and exports during these four years have grown £34,312,000 to £41,125.00 a rise of 20 pet
cent, the increase in imports having been 7 . per cent and in exporta over 33 per cent,

div.head: CHILD BIRTH AND KIDNEY DISEASE.
div.p: BODY BLOATED WITH DROPSY.

Mrs W. Brown, 8 South-Western Cottages, Dorchester, England, says : "For fifteen years I suffered with my kidneys It started with a confinement and everyx confine mont aftorwards left me worse than before. My back gave me the most trouble; across the small part of it was a dreadful feeling, just as if a knife were being put into my back, the pain taking my breath away. I did not know how to turn over in bed or how to get up in the mornings, for there was always a gnawing ache in my back, and the least cold would settle there.

*The urinary secretions were in a dread, ful condition. They caused awful pain, and sometimes I was unable to pass them. 1] became very much bluated in the body, legs and face, and there were bage 4 of 1 water under my eyes, making them very.. tender. I was unable to fasten up my clothes properly, because of the swellings.

"I decided to try Doan's Backache Kid ney Pills and noticedoliongoon after began using them, the flrst benefit being that I awoke feeling free of pain, and with an appetite. Keeping on with the pills the paids grew less frequent, I felt bettor in myself, and the kidney secretions became clear and natural. Now I am feeling abgolutely well – it is the first spell of good health I have had for fifteen years. My cure is all the more wonderful because my complaint is inherited, being a family-one.
(Signed) W. Brown."

Going on for six months later & representative called to see her. "My health in first-rate," said Mrs. Brown. "My cure is. lasting one. Friends say to me, "Why, you cet look younger instead of older."

Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all nu chemists and druggists at 13 P.T. per box, de or 71 P.T. for 6 boxes; or they may be me had direct from the agents for Egypt Mr. (L E. div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Il n'y a pas grand'chose de changé dans la situation d'hier, sinon qu'il y a peut-être en certain ralentissement dans les transactions. Mais les prix sont soutenus en général et quel ques titres gagnent même me ayance apprécia ble. La baisse nouvelle du taux privé d'escompte à 4% ainsi que la remarquable fermete des va leurs égyptiennes au Stock Exchange ont naturellemgat contribué notre soqtien local. La seule réserve à faire, comme nous le disions hier, est que jusqu'à présent les paquets n'ayant pas effectivement changé de mains une réaction est toujours à craindre au cas o les évé. nements prendraient une autre tournure.

Parmi les titres da faveur il nous faut signa ler la National Bank qui progroase de 20 7/8 # 21 1/16, la "Delta Light de 91/2 = 99/16 ot. la Dalra do 18 7/16 a 18 11/16. Les Obligations Crédit Foncier, a cause d'une demande qui n'a pu être satisfaite, a passé de 2-7 à 298 l'ancienne et de 256 à 958 la nouvelle. En syance également l'Alexandria Water de 10 1/4 A 10 5/46, les Nangovich Hotels de 13 & 13 1/4 et le Banco di Roma de 107 à 108..

Dans lo poupe des valeurs de moindre im. portanoe, la Cassa di Sconto moute de 52 A 52 1/2, les Estates de 11/82 à 3,8 et les Building Lands, après être restées longtemps délaissées aux environs de 1 livre, 'se relèvent à 1 3/8, en hausse de 1/8 sur le prix d'hier. 1 Malboureusement la reprise n'est pas générale et plusieurs titres qui avaient joui d'une certaine vogue ces temps pamor pubis sent one dépression plus ou moins marquée. La deferred Doltar revient de -5 1.8 5, la Delta Land de 1 5/32 4 118, l'ordinary Khedivial Mail de 19/- á 18/6, le Comptoir de 2 5/16 à 2 9/32, l'Aboukir de 34 - à 33 3, et l'action Land Allotment de 1 15.16 à 178. Mais la baisse la plas sensible est celle de la Nile Land de 78/4 a 7 1/4. Il faut dire pour cette dernière que les prix sont plutôt nominaux, les transations sur de titre étant clairsemées et pres. que nulles.
Les Rita et l'United, qui s'étaient réveillés ces jours-ci, sont également retombés momentanément dans l'oubli, délaissés aux prix respectifs de 3,8 et 1/4.
Il n'y a pas d'autre changement signaler, que l'inscription de la Ramleh à 4 3/16 ex, coupon contre 4 7/16 hier. La différence repré. sente le coupon distribué.

Comme on lo' voit, - la tendance est inégale Pour quelques valeurs favorisées par les mar. chés européens ou poussées par la spéculation locale il y a nouvelle avance, tandis que pour d'autres moins importautes et moins nom breuses aussi, o'est la faiblesse et la lourdear qui prévalent. Dans l'ensemble, cependant, si les affaires se sont quelque peu marétées, on peat considérer la cote comme soutenue et la tondanoe générale comme favorable.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe.
Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.&O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis” to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt,” by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

It is hardly necessary to point out to Tourists the extraordinary interest of a visit to Athens from an artistic, historical and archaelogical point of view, and if possible tourists should average to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara, for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

la Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux d'asphaltage d'une partie de la rue Porte Rouette.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE 1800.
Le cahier des charges est dépose au burea Technique où il peut être consult. par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h à midi, les jours fériés except
Les offres devront otre adresscos sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 24 Février 1908.
Elles pourront également de déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour 5 l. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : "Soumission pour Asphaltage ruo Porto Rosette.

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale, avant l'ouverture des offres et au plas tard le 24 Février 1908 à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée. Alexandrio le 11 Janvier 1908.
